Legal_Issue: Reasonableness and clarity of the citizenship judge's decision on residency under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant lacked sufficient physical presence in Canada but maintained familial and business ties
Decision_Outcome: Decision found unreasonable due to lack of clarity
Court_Ruling: Appeal granted; application remitted for re-determination
Claimant_Status: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Defendant_Behavior: Failed to clearly articulate the residency test applied
Grounds_for_Claim: Unclear reasoning on fulfillment of residency requirement
Assessment_Factor: Choice and application of residency test: quantitative, qualitative, or centralized mode of living
Procedural_Issue: Failure to specify the legal test used in assessing residency
Evidence_Used: Family ties, business connections, duration of physical presence in Canada
Application_Basis: Accumulation of at least 1095 days of residence in Canada over four years
Evidence_Assessed: Physical presence, strength of attachment to Canada, residential stability
Relief_Sought: Overturning of citizenship approval and remittal for redetermination
Governing_Rule: Applicants must meet minimum residency requirement through one of three interpretive tests
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of explanation regarding which test was used and how it was applied
Outcome: Appeal granted, case remanded to a different judge
Harm_Assessment: Risk of improper grant of citizenship due to unclear legal analysis
Cause_Description: Minister appealed the approval of citizenship application citing unclear reasoning on residency requirement
Evidence_Handling: Court found insufficient articulation of how evidence was weighed under any recognized test
Evidence_Issues: Insufficient linkage between evidence and chosen legal test
Evidence_Assessment: Incomplete due to failure to apply a defined analytical framework
Decision_Rationale: Decision was unreasonable due to lack of transparency and clarity in applying the law
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to connect factual findings with legal test
